subject: Art
title: Facial Expressions
description: The eyebrows, mouth, and eyes that make characters feel alive.

hook.text: Two dots and a curved line = a face. Move the curve down = sad. Add angled lines above the dots = angry. Humans are hardwired to read faces â€” and even the simplest marks trigger emotional recognition.

buildup.text: The three expression drivers: eyebrows (emotion type â€” angled = angry, raised = surprised, curved = worried), eyes (intensity â€” wide = alert/scared, narrow = suspicious/happy), mouth (valence â€” up = happy, down = sad, open = shocked).

discovery.text: The eyebrow-mouth relationship: when both agree (angry brows + frown), the expression is clear. When they conflict (angry brows + smile), you get complex emotions (smugness, menace, sarcasm). Conflict creates nuance.

twist.text: Asymmetry adds life: one eyebrow raised higher than the other suggests questioning or skepticism. A half-smile (one corner up) reads as wry or uncertain. Real faces are asymmetrical â€” illustrated ones should be too.

climax.text: Draw the same face 9 times in a 3Ã—3 grid. Give each a different expression: happy, sad, angry, surprised, scared, disgusted, confused, smug, and peaceful. Use only eyebrows, eyes, and mouth. You'll be amazed at how little you need.

punchline.text: Master faces and your characters breathe. Two dots and a line can make someone laugh or cry.

quiz.question: What creates complex, nuanced facial expressions in illustration?
options: Conflicting signals â€” such as angry eyebrows paired with a smile
